title: Fainting
summary: Managing fainting episodes and helping someone who has lost consciousness briefly due to reduced blood flow to the brain.

steps.title: Catch or Ease to Ground
steps.description: If person is about to faint (dizzy, pale, sweating), help them lie down immediately. If already falling, try to guide them down gently to prevent injury. Clear area of dangerous objects.

steps.title: Position for Blood Flow
steps.description: Lay person on back and elevate legs 12 inches to improve blood flow to brain. Loosen tight clothing especially around neck. If vomiting, turn on side. Most people recover within a minute.

steps.title: Check Responsiveness
steps.description: Check if person is breathing normally. They should regain consciousness within 1-2 minutes. If not responding after 1 minute, call 911. If not breathing, begin CPR immediately.

steps.title: Recovery Care
steps.description: Once conscious, keep lying down for 10-15 minutes. Give sips of water if fully alert. Check for injuries from fall. Person may feel confused or nauseated. Cool compress on forehead may help.

steps.title: Monitor Before Standing
steps.description: Help person sit up slowly after 10-15 minutes. Wait several minutes before standing. Stand slowly and sit immediately if dizzy. Stay with them until fully recovered. Seek medical evaluation for cause.

warnings: Fainting can be sign of serious condition - always seek medical evaluation
Do not give anything by mouth until fully conscious
Repeated fainting episodes require immediate medical attention
whenToSeekHelp: Call 911 if person doesn't regain consciousness within 2 minutes
Seek immediate care for fainting with chest pain or irregular heartbeat
Get medical evaluation after any fainting episode to determine cause
preventionTips: Stay hydrated and don't skip meals
Stand up slowly from sitting or lying positions
Avoid standing still for long periods in hot weather
